content:
Sure, here's a more detailed version of the data model in tabular format using markdown:

| Entity | Attributes |
| --- | --- |
| Patient | ID, First Name, Last Name, Date of Birth, Gender, Contact Information, Insurance Details |
| Healthcare Provider | ID, First Name, Last Name, Contact Information, Credentials |
| Medication | ID, Name, Dosage, Frequency, Route of Administration |
| Prescription | ID, Patient ID (FK), Healthcare Provider ID (FK), Medication ID (FK), Dosage Instructions, Special Instructions |
| Pharmacy | ID, Name, Location, Contact Information |
| Transaction | ID, Prescription ID (FK), Date/Time Sent, Date/Time Received, Date/Time Filled, Patient ID (FK), Healthcare Provider ID (FK), Pharmacy ID (FK), Billing/Insurance Information |

In this data model, each entity has a unique ID, and the Prescription entity has foreign keys (FK) that reference the Patient, Healthcare Provider, and Medication entities. The Transaction entity has foreign keys that reference the Prescription, Patient, Healthcare Provider, and Pharmacy entities.

This data model allows for the tracking of prescriptions, patients, healthcare providers, medications, and pharmacies, as well as the transactional history related to each prescription. With this data model, it is possible to perform queries to track prescription filling rates, monitor medication adherence, and identify potential drug interactions or adverse events.
